case_name: Tinnevelli-Tuticorin Electric Supply Co., Ltd. v. Its Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 23 of 1958 filed by special leave in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 23 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the decision dated September 29, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, in Appeal  Mad.  No. 96 of 1956, arising out of the Award dated April 9, 1956, of the Industrial Tribunal., Madras, in I.D. No. 52 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal arises from decision dated September 29, 1956 of Labour Appellate Tribunal, Bombay in Appeal Mad. No. 96 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated September 29, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, in Appeal  Mad.  No. 96 of 1956, arising out of the Award dated April 9, 1956, of the Industrial Tribunal., Madras, in I.D. No. 52 of 1954. V. Viswanatha Sastri, and Naunit Lal, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appeal Mad. No. 96 of 1956 arises out of Award dated April 9, 1956 of Industrial Tribunal, Madras in I.D. No. 52 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated September 29, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, in Appeal  Mad.  No. 96 of 1956, arising out of the Award dated April 9, 1956, of the Industrial Tribunal., Madras, in I.D. No. 52 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellant is Tinnevelli-Tuticorin Electric Supply Co., Ltd., Tuticorin, an electric supply undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The appellant, the Tinnevelli-Tuticorin Electric Supply Co., Ltd., Tuticorin, is an electric supply undertaking, and it carries on its business as a licensee under the State Government of Madras subject to the provisions of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910  Act 9 of 1910  and the Electric Supply Act, 1948  Act 54 of 1948 .

facts.text: Appellant carries on business as licensee under State Government of Madras subject to Indian Electricity Act, 1910 and Electric Supply Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and it carries on its business as a licensee under the State Government of Madras subject to the provisions of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910  Act 9 of 1910  and the Electric Supply Act, 1948  Act 54 of 1948 . This latter Act will hereinafter be called the Act.

facts.text: Appellant's business consists of buying electric supply from State Hydro-electric Projects and supplying to consumers in areas around Tinnevelly and Tuticorin Municipalities.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the appellant companysists of buying electric supply from the State Hydro-electric Projects and of supplying the same to companysumers within the areas specified in its licence this area is in and around Tinnevelli and Tuticorin Municipalities.

facts.text: Appellant's workmen (respondents) made demands in respect of terms of employment leading to industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants workmen  hereinafter called the respondents  made several demands in respect of their terms of employment. These demands gave rise to an industrial dispute which was referred by the Madras Government to the Industrial Tribunal at Madurai for adjudication under s. 10 1  c  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  XIV of 1947 .

facts.text: Industrial dispute referred by Madras Government to Industrial Tribunal at Madurai under s.10(1)(c) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 in I.D. No. 52 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: These demands gave rise to an industrial dispute which was referred by the Madras Government to the Industrial Tribunal at Madurai for adjudication under s. 10 1  c  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  XIV of 1947 . Amongst the items thus referred for adjudication was included the respondents claim for additional bonus for the year 1952-

facts.text: Respondents claimed additional bonus for the year 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst the items thus referred for adjudication was included the respondents claim for additional bonus for the year 1952- Without prejudice to its companytention that the appellant was number liable to pay bonus it had in fact voluntarily paid two months basic wages by way of bonus to the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant voluntarily paid two months basic wages by way of bonus to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Without prejudice to its companytention that the appellant was number liable to pay bonus it had in fact voluntarily paid two months basic wages by way of bonus to the respondents. The respondents, however, claimed additional bonus and this claim was one of the items of dispute referred to the tribunal for its adjudication.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal rejected appellant's contentions and held liable to pay two months basic wages as additional bonus; award passed on March 4, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal, however, rejected the appellants companytentions and held that the appellant was liable to pay two months basic wages as additional bonus to the respondents. This award was passed on March 4, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal No. 56 of 1955 to Labour Appellate Tribunal against award of March 4, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Against this award the appellant preferred an appeal, No. 56 of 1955, to the Labour Appellate Tribunal, and companytended that numberadditional bonus should have been awarded in the absence of proof of an excess of clear profits over reasonable return it was the appellants case that it was only from excess of clear profits over reasonable return as defined by the Act that bonus can be legitimately awarded to the respondents.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal fuller bench held bonus could be ordered notwithstanding limitations of Act, applied Full Bench formula, remanded appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The special bench of the appellate tribunal then heard the group of appeals including the appeal preferred by the appellant. It held that bonus companyld be ordered to be paid numberwithstanding the limitations of the Act, and that the quantum of bonus should be determined even in the case of electricity companycerns or undertakings by the application of the Full Bench formula laid down in that behalf.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal at Madurai abolished, appeals transferred to Industrial Tribunal at Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal preferred by the appellant was in due companyrse taken up by the Industrial Tribunal at Madras the Industrial Tribunal at Madurai having been in the meanwhile abolished and the appeals on its file transferred to the Industrial Tribunal at Madras.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal Madras passed award on April 9, 1956 directing appellant to pay additional bonus of two months basic wages.

anchor.surface_text: This latter tribunal companysidered the merits of the companytentions raised by the parties, applied the Full Bench formula, and ultimately passed an award on April 9, 1956, directing the appellant to pay an additional bonus of two months basic wages to the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant preferred Appeal Madras No. 96 of 1956 to Labour Appellate Tribunal against April 9, 1956 award.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant preferred another appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal, and it was numbered as Appeal  Madras  No. 96 of 1956.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal in Appeal No. 96/1956 held additional bonus of one month's basic wage after rectifying calculation error.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal negatived most of the companytentions raised by the appellant, but it was satisfied that the calculation made by the tribunal in regard to the quantum of available surplus was erroneous, and so, after rectifying the said error, it held that the additional bonus which the appellant should pay to the respondents was one months basic wage.

facts.text: Appellant contended before Industrial Tribunal that no claim for bonus admissible outside provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Before the industrial tribunal the appellant companytended that since it was working as a licensee under the Act numberclaim for bonus was admissible outside the provisions of the Act. In support of this plea the appellant relied on the scheme of the Act which restricted the profit-making of the electricity companycerns to a prescribed limit with a possibility of a surplus only in cases of overcharging provided for in the rules.

facts.text: Judgment of Supreme Court delivered on February 22, 1960 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, and Naunit Lal, for the appellants. S. Venkataraman and M. K. Ramamurth, for the respondents. 1960. February, 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Full Bench formula applies to bonus claims against electricity concerns notwithstanding the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the Labour Appellate Tribunal was right in companying to the companyclusion that the respondents claim for bonus must be governed by the application of the Full Bench formula.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal conceded income-tax at seven annas in rupee and contingency reserve of Rs. 6,047, normal statutory depreciation Rs. 99,038.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Labour Appellate Tribunal it was fairly companyceded by the respondents that at least income-tax at seven annas in a rupee on the gross profits less depreciation, and also a companytingency reserve of Rs. 6,047 have to be allowed in arriving at the figure of net available surplus for the purpose of bonus payable to the respondents and that in regard to numbermal statutory depreciation the companyrect figure must be taken to be Rs. 99,038 instead of Rs. 90,393 as given by the industrial tribunal.

facts.text: Appellant led no evidence on rehabilitation claim before Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Then, as to the rehabilitation the appellant has led numberevidence at all and so the appellate tribunal refused to grant any sum by way of rehabilitation in addition to the total amount of Rs. 1,13,950.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal rejected appellant's triple shift allowance claim for mains, cables and wires.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim for the triple shift allowance in respect of the mains has been allowed by the appellate tribunal and there is numberdispute in respect of it but it is urged that rule 8 of the Incometax Rules justifies the appellants claim in respect of all its electric plant and machinery under Entry IIIE  1 .

facts.text: Appellant claimed Rs. 23,516 provision for extra shift depreciation on cables and wires.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim for the provision of Rs. 23,516 in that behalf was therefore, rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Labour Appellate Tribunal's rejection of rehabilitation and extra shift claims due to lack of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appellate tribunal was right in holding that the adoption of a factor of 2-7 for all assets purchased before 1945 was number justified, and that the adoption of the figures of the estimated life of the assets from the Schedule to the Electric Supply Act without even deducting the respective portions of the life of the assets which had already expired was equally unjustified.

arguments.claim: Act is self-contained code regulating business including bonus claims; dispute decided solely by Act, not Full Bench formula

anchor.surface_text: It is urged on behalf of the appellant that it is only where the clear profits are in excess of the reasonable return under the Act that a case for the payment of bonus can really arise in regard to the electricity concerns and undertakings. The Act is a self-contained code intended to regulate the business and affairs of electricity concerns including the claim of their employees for bonus, and as such an industrial dispute between such concerns and their employees in regard to bonus must be determined solely by reference to the provisions of the Act and not by the application of the Full Bench formula.

arguments.court_reasoning: Fields covered different: Act for rates/consumers, formula for social justice/bonus; no conflict

anchor.surface_text: As to the quantum of bonus which should be awarded it would depend upon the circumstances in each case but it is urged that it may as an ad hoc measure be decided that 1/4th of the excess between clear profits and the reasonable return may be taken as a fair quantum of bonus which electricity concerns should be ordered to pay to their employees.

arguments.claim: Bonus not included under para 17(2)(b)(xi) as not arising from/ancillary/incidental to electricity supply business though admissible under IT Act

anchor.surface_text: The next question which arises is whether a claim for bonus can be said to be included under paragraph 17 2 b xi . This provision includes under expenditure other expenses admissible under the law for the time being in force in the assessment of Indian Income-tax and arising from. and ancillary or incidental to, the business of electricity supply. It is admitted that bonus paid by an employer to his employees constitutes expenses admissible under section 10 2 vi of the Income-tax Act, but it is urged that it is not an expense which can be said to arise from, and ancillary or incidental to, the business of electricity supply.

In our opinion, the appellate tribunal was right in holding that the adoption of a factor of 2-7 for all assets purchased before 1945 was not justified, and that the adoption of the figures of the estimated life of the assets from the Schedule to the Electric Supply Act without even deducting the respective portions of the life of the assets which had already expired was equally unjustified.

The appellants claim for the provision of Rs. 23,516 in that behalf was therefore, rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal negatived most of the contentions raised by the appellant, but it was satisfied that the calculation made by the tribunal in regard to the quantum of available surplus was erroneous, and so, after rectifying the said error, it held that the additional bonus which the appellant should pay to the respondents was one months basic wage.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the appeal preferred by the appellant. It held that bonus companyld be ordered to be paid numberwithstanding the limitations of the Act, and that the

arguments.court_reasoning: Upheld rectification but overall formula accepted

arguments.claim: Full Bench formula governs bonus claim; Act covers different field (rates/returns vs social justice/wages)

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for our decision is whether the appellant is right in contending that the present dispute arising from the respondents claim for bonus must be decided by the provisions of the Act alone and that the Full Bench formula is wholly inapplicable for the purpose. In dealing with this contention it is necessary to bear in mind that the fields covered by the Full Bench formula and by the provisions of the Act are entirely different.

arguments.claim: Bonus included in para 17(2)(b)(xi) as expense admissible under IT and ancillary to business

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal has held that even the other test is satisfied and that the expenditure in question can be said to arise from, or to be ancillary, or incidental to, the business of electricity supply. In our opinion, it is difficult to accept the appellants argument that the construction placed by the appellate tribunal on the latter part of this clause is not reasonably possible.

arguments.claim: No rehabilitation as no evidence; factor 2.7 and undeducted life unjustified

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appellate tribunal was right in holding that the adoption of a factor of 2-7 for all assets purchased before 1945 was not justified, and that the adoption of the figures of the estimated life of the assets from the Schedule to the Electric Supply Act without even deducting the respective portions of the life of the assets which had already expired was equally unjustified.

arguments.claim: No extra shift depreciation for cables/wires as under IIIC(4)(5) NESA; insufficient material

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal has observed that the appellant made no attempt to show that any such claim for shift depreciation in respect of its cables and wires had been put forward by it before the income-tax authorities, or that it was held to be admissible by them. ... In such a case we do not see how we can interfere in favour of the appellant.

holdings.text: The Full Bench formula can and should be applied in adjudicating upon the respondents' claim for bonus against the appellant, an electricity supply undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: The main question which the appeal raises for our decision is whether the fuller bench of the Labour Appellate Tribunal was justified in holding that the Full Bench formula can and should be applied in adjudicating upon the respondents claim for bonus against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fields covered by Act (regulation of rates, returns for consumers) and Full Bench formula (social justice, bonus from commercial profits) are different; no conflict; commercial accounts basis for gross profits.

holdings.text: The present dispute arising from the respondents' claim for bonus must not be decided solely by the provisions of the Act; the Full Bench formula is applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for our decision is whether the appellant is right in contending that the present dispute arising from the respondents claim for bonus must be decided by the provisions of the Act alone and that the Full Bench formula is wholly inapplicable for the purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act's working-sheet differs from commercial profit/loss accounts used in formula; Act silent on wages/bonus; social justice principles govern industrial adjudication.

holdings.text: An amount of bonus paid by the employer to his employees is included under paragraph 17(2)(b)(xi) of the Sixth Schedule as 'other expenses admissible under Income-tax Act arising from/ancillary/incidental to electricity supply business'.

anchor.surface_text: One of the points which we have to decide in the present appeal is whether an amount of bonus paid by the employer to his employees is included under paragraph 17  2   b  xi  of the Sixth Schdule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bonus admissible under IT Act s.10(2)(vi); ancillary to business per tribunal construction, which is reasonable; 1957 amendment cl.xiii clarifies original intent.

holdings.text: A claim for bonus is included under paragraph 17(2)(b)(xi) of the Sixth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The next question which arises is whether a claim for bonus can be said to be included under paragraph 17  2   b   xi .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfies both tests: IT admissible and ancillary/incidental to supply business; legislative clarification via amendment.

holdings.text: Appellant's claim for rehabilitation rejected; adoption of factor 2.7 for pre-1945 assets and undeducted asset life from Schedule unjustified due to lack of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Then, as to the rehabilitation the appellant has led no evidence at all and so the appellate tribunal refused to grant any sum by way of rehabilitation in addition to the total amount of Rs. 1,13,950. In our opinion, the appellate tribunal was right in holding that the adoption of a factor of 2-7 for all assets purchased before 1945 was not justified, and that the adoption of the figures of the estimated life of the assets from the Schedule to the Electric Supply Act without even deducting the respective portions of the life of the assets which had already expired was equally unjustified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence led by appellant; arbitrary methods not justified.

holdings.text: Appellant's claim for extra shift depreciation on cables and wires (Rs.23,516) rejected; falls under IIIC(4)&(5) NESA, no evidence of IT allowance or greater depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim for the triple shift allowance in respect of the mains has been allowed by the appellate tribunal and there is no dispute in respect of it but it is urged that rule 8 of the Income-tax Rules justifies the appellants claim in respect of all its electric plant and machinery under Entry IIIE  1 . ... The appellants claim for the provision of Rs. 23,516 in that behalf was therefore, rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 8 entries distinguish; no proof before IT authorities; insufficient material on record.

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal right in its calculation rectification; additional bonus of one month's basic wage upheld.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal negatived most of the contentions raised by the appellant, but it was satisfied that the calculation made by the tribunal in regard to the quantum of available surplus was erroneous, and so, after rectifying the said error, it held that the additional bonus which the appellant should pay to the respondents was one months basic wage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error in quantum conceded; no interference warranted on merits.

precedents.citation: U. P. Electricity Supply Co. Ltd. Ors. v. Their Workmen 1 [1955 L.A.C. 659]

anchor.surface_text: U. P. Electricity Supply Co. Ltd. Ors. v. Their Workmen  1  has decided two questions of law. The first was in regard to the applicability of the Full Bench formula to the employees claim for bonus against their employers carrying on the business of the supply of electricity, and the second was in regard to the extent of the statutory depreciation allowed by the Full Bench formula. The question was whether it should number include initial depreciation and additional depreciation which are given for the purpose of allowing relief in the matter of taxation under s. 10 2   vi-b  of the Income-tax Act. The fuller bench had decided that in allowing a prior charge in the  1   1955  L.A.C. 659.

precedents.case_name: U. P. Electricity Supply Co. Ltd. Ors. v. Their Workmen

anchor.surface_text: The correctness of this latter decision was challenged before this Court in Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1  but the challenge failed and the decision of the fuller bench was confirmed. In the present appeal it is the correctness of the fuller bench decision on the first question which is challenged before us. Let us being by stating briefly the appellants contention.

precedents.case_name: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen

precedents.citation: Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen 1 [1957 S.C.R. 33]

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it may be useful to refer to the decision of this Court in the case of Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen  1 . One of the points raised on behalf of the Baroda Borough Municipality in resisting the claim for bonus by its workmen was that the scheme of the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act 18 of 1925 by which the Municipality was governed did number permit the making of any claim for bonus and so it was number open to the, labour court or tribunal to direct payment of bonus to municipal employees.- This argument was rejected. The demand for bonus as an industrial claim , it was  1  1957 S.C.R. 33.

precedents.case_name: Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Scheme of governing statute like Municipal Act does not bar bonus claims which are governed by Industrial Disputes Act
precedents.cited_holding: absence of provisions in Municipal Act for bonus not determinative; bonus claim under ID Act irrespective of municipal scheme
